Award.AwardTitle: EDURange: Supporting cyber security education with hands-on exercises, a student-staffed help-desk, and webinars

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The EDURange project, a collaboration between Evergreen State College and Lewis and Clark College, will support faculty teaching cyber security by providing hands-on exercises, a student-staffed help-desk, and webinars. These resources will be designed to be easy to deploy and will be interactive, competitive and collaborative to ensure student engagement. The availability of these resources will make it easier for computer science faculty with little prior background to teach security across, and will increase the number of schools teaching cyber security concepts. As a result this project will produce more students with the analytical skills required to secure computing assets in the Pacific Northwest and in turn will help to ensure American technical competitiveness in the future.

The resources will be linked to the concepts and learning outcomes defined in the IEEE/ACM CS Curricula 2013 report. Support for these resources will be provided by a student-run help desk and a user interface that will allow faculty to modify exercises to fit the content and level of difficulty of their classes. Background material will be provided for students to make the exercises applicable to a variety of computer science classes. These resources will fulfill four important needs: (1) expanding and disseminating technology ? improving exercises using EDURange, a flexible, cloud-based teaching infrastructure, (2) faculty development ? helping them use hands-on security exercises in their classrooms and providing curricular resources, (3) student engagement ? developing their skills, leveraging their talent and knowledge, and mentoring them to become the next generation of teachers and researchers, and (4) education research --investigating the acquisition of analytical skills.

Assessment of the resources will focus on four activities: (1) a quantitative evaluation and summary of how often and how widely the resources are used, (2) a qualitative assessment of how well exercises map or express the cyber security knowledge units of CS2013, (3) an assessment of faculty experience using the resources in their courses, and (4) an evaluation of the experience using the resources by security faculty, professionals, and students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The world has an urgent need for qualified cyber defense professionals. The critical shortage of cybersecurity professionals remains a pressing problem. We need to greatly expand the community of faculty teaching cybersecurity and the number of students they can teach. Developing hands-on exercises that are easy to use is an important step. Faculty are reluctant to use exercises that they cannot adapt to their courses. The EDURange project has developed a framework that is designed to make it easy for faculty to create new exercises and modify existing ones.  In addition to creating the framework, we have created six new exercises (in addition to the original two) that have been tested in the classroom at several colleges and have been tried by over 100 faculty. We held three webinars in addition to hands-on workshops at SIGCSE and CCSC-NW Two independent faculty have contributed their own exercises. The EDURange user interface has been continuously improved, including extensive work on documentation for students and faculty. We have made it possible for faculty to use an exercise with just a few clicks. The exercises are engaging for students and some of them have been gamefied. Students have ranked our exercises at least as high and sometimes higher than other publically available hands-on exercises. This project has also provided dozens of opportunities for undergraduate research.

 

Another important aspect of creating curricular tools is assessment. Faculty need to be able to assess student progress easily and this needs to scale well with class size. This capability has been part of EDURange since 2016 and was enhanced by this grant. EDURange provides faculty with the ability to see the sequence of commands that each student has typed in both textual and graphical formats. 

 

EDURange is cloud-based. This was part of the original design so that faculty would not need to be system administrators. As cloud computing becomes more commonplace, faculty will have greater access to AWS and will be able to use EDURange on their own accounts, and will not require our resources.
